intro.value: When you spend a lot of time in the same place, you start to notice little things you‚Äôd overlooked in the past.

#quarantine2020 has personally made me hyper-aware of the words that Netflix uses to tag its programs. Check out the 43 titles and tags that Netflix displayed on my TV‚Äôs screensaver and see if you notice what I did.

postTv.value: Did you see it? The high-level categories like drama and comedy are going the way of the video stores that depended on them for categorization. Only to be replaced with words like irreverent.

The use of irreverent in particular has become something that I can‚Äôt. Stop. Noticing. And it‚Äôs not hard to see why. It was the most popular descriptive word shown to me across a wide variety of programs.

Now, I know what you‚Äôre going to say. Netflix‚Äôs algorithms are probably advertising things that it thinks I would like based on my own viewing preferences. It‚Äôs definitely possible that I am causing my own irreverent doom.
So, I created a brand new profile with no viewing preferences and recorded the tags for the first 141 shows on the Netflix homepage. Irreverent is still the second most common.

postTiger.value: Well, with the decision fatigue I‚Äôve been feeling, let‚Äôs just say that I sat and watched that screensaver. A lot. And I started feeling like I was seeing ‚Äúirreverent‚Äù everywhere. I wanted to know if this was real or if it was the weeks of staring at the 4 walls of my studio apartment just getting to me. post-highlight.value: Ok, so, before you say it, I know how Netflix works. It suggests titles to me that it assumes I would like, so maybe the overabundance of irreverent shows in my ads was due to my own streaming preferences. Had I been unwittingly causing my own irreverent doom?!

So I dug deeper, creating a brand new profile, providing it with no preferences at all, and found the descriptive words that appeared alongside each hovered thumbnail when you visit Netflix on a computer (the same words that were appearing on my screensaver). Out of these 141 titles, and 79 unique descriptive words, irreverent was still the second most common.

conclusion.value: So these are titles that poke fun at things that may come across as disrespectful or offensive. Titles like The Hangover (absurd, raunchy), The Office (witty, sitcom), and Step Brothers (slapstick, raunchy) may seem to fit the bill well and are considered irreverent by Netflix. Using irreverent as a tag for these titles (assuming that you know what it means) will at least give you an accurate heads up about what you‚Äôre about to watch.

But other titles, like Orange is the New Black, a ‚Äúdramedy‚Äù centered around the experiences of people residing in a women‚Äôs prison is described as deadpan, witty, and irreverent. To describe this series in the same way as Derry Girls does new viewers that may not be expecting the heavy drama element of the show a disservice.

Even still, other titles like Grace and Frankie, a show devoted to the post-divorce life of two women who (among many other things) develop a line of vibrators for the elderly, are apparently not irreverent. The show is described as heartfelt, witty, and quirky. I‚Äôm certainly not here to advocate that we should be using this word to describe more titles, but it seems like its use is inconsistent at best and misleading to viewers at worst.

I know that with everything going on in the world right now, the words Netflix uses to describe their titles probably feels like the least important thing. I‚Äôm not even about to argue with you about that. But as stay-at-home orders continue across the world, Netflix usage is booming. The global platform saw an astounding 15.7 million new subscribers in the past quarter, double what they had been anticipating. Back in March, they even cut streaming quality in Europe to help offset the increased data consumption by home-bound streamers.

As all of these new and old users log in and look for something new to watch, they rely on the information Netflix provides to help them choose their next piece of entertainment. Back in the day when the platform opted for one-two sentence descriptions, users had thoughts. The descriptions tended to be technically accurate, but not exactly useful. According to an investigation from The Outline in 2017, this can be partially attributed to the fact that the synopsis writers were not paid ‚Äúwell enough...to actually watch the movies‚Äù. That was a few years and a different synopsis system ago, so I‚Äôm hopeful that things have changed at Netflix since then.

But still, it makes me wonder who is selecting these words and why irreverent is used so profusely. Are we assuming this word (which is technically a real genre of comedy) is well-understood by viewers? And I if this many shows are poking fun at ‚Äúthings generally taken seriously‚Äù, are those things actually taken seriously anymore? If this many things are irreverent, is anything?
